pageData.text: The common types of chemical reactions are studied and performed in this investigation, including synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, double replacement, and combustion. Chemical products are predicted for each reaction based on observations and chemical tests. A balanced chemical equation will be written for each reaction. After the investigation, a series of known reactions will be presented to classify and balance.

text: Describe common types of chemical reactions.
Predict products from common chemical reactions, including synthesis, decomposition, single replacement, double replacement, and combustion.
Write balanced chemical equations.
Classify chemical reactions by type.
Identify heat as a possible product or reactant.

pageData.text: Molecular gastronomists use science to create delicious food creations. For example, they can make a flourless chocolate cake using a jellified emulsion where the protein network of whipped egg whites carefully traps microscopic drops of chocolate<sup class=bodySupscript>1</sup>. Or they use scientific equipment, like funnels and liquid nitrogen, in addition to the traditional tools of a professional kitchen.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>These culinary mavericks understand that cooking is just a series of chemical reactions. With this mindset, molecular gastronomists often employ a unique approach to recipe documentation. In the early 2000s, the Congress of the European Colloid and Interface Society introduced the use of letters and symbols to represent general recipe formats rather than traditional measurements such as cups, grams, or teaspoons. For example, a recipe for whipping cream looks more like a chemical reaction than a traditional recipe: O/W + G → (O + G)/W, where G represents a gas, O represents a liquid fat, W is an aqueous solution, and S is a solid<sup>1</sup>.
1Burke, M. (2020, January 29). Cooking with chemistry. Chemistry World News.https://www.chemistryworld.com/news/cooking-with-chemistry/3001121.article?msclkid=0791e89cac5e11ecbbf3846098b663dc

pageData.desc: A shallow bowl filled with an artfully arranged mound of whipped cream surrounded and topped by fresh raspberries.
pageData.altText: A shallow bowl filled with an artfully arranged mound of whipped cream surrounded and topped by fresh raspberries.

pageData.text:
Knowing how to recognize common types of chemical reactions allows a chemist to accurately predict the products of a given reaction. Chemical reactions can be grouped into the following five common reaction types: (1) synthesis, (2) decomposition, (3) single replacement, (4) double replacement, and (5) combustion.1. Synthesis Reactions
Synthesis means to combine or put together. These reactions are sometimes referred to as combination reactions. In a , two or more reactants combine to make a single new product.A + B → AB

Examples of synthesis reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>C(s) + O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) → CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + Heat</br>H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(l) + SO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(g) → H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>SO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq)

2. Decomposition Reactions
Decomposition means to break down. In a , a single reactant compound breaks down to form two or more new products.
AB → A + B

Examples of decomposition reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(aq) → H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(l) + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + Heat</br>CaCO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(s) → CaO(s) + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g)</br>2Nl<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub> → N<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + 3l<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(s)

pageData.altText: Types of Chemical Reactions

pageData.text:
3. Single-Replacement Reactions
occur when a single element in one reactant replaces a similar single element in another reactant. This reaction is sometimes called a displacement or substitution reaction.A + BC → AC + B

Examples of single-replacement reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Zn(s) + CuSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq) → ZnSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq) + Cu(s)</br>Fe<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(s) + 2Al(s) → 2Fe(s) + Al<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(s) + Heat

4. Double-Replacement Reactions
In , two ionic compounds exchange ions to produce two new ionic compounds. This reaction is sometimes called a metathesis reaction. The reactants are usually aqueous solutions, and the driving force is the formation of a precipitate, gas, or liquid product. When the product is a precipitate, the reaction is called a precipitation reaction.AB + CD → AD + CB

Examples of double-replacement reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>NaCl(aq) + AgNO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(aq) → NaNO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(aq) + AgCl(s) </br>BaCl<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(aq) + Na<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>SO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq) → BaSO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(s) + 2NaCl(aq)

One type of double-replacement reaction is an acid-base reaction, in which a reaction occurs between an acid and a base. A hydronium ion (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) reacts with a hydroxide ion (OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>) to form water, and the cation and anion form an aqueous salt.

Examples of acid–base reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>HCl(aq) + NaOH(aq) → NaCl(aq) + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(l)</br>H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>SO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq) + 2NH<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>OH(aq) → (NH<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>)<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>SO<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(aq) + H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(l)

5. Combustion Reactions
involve a single element or compound that combines with oxygen gas to release heat and light. This rapid oxidation is commonly called burning.

Examples of single-element combustion reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>C(s) + O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) → CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + Energy </br>2Mg(s) + O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) → 2MgO + Energy

Hydrocarbons are prime examples of compounds that react with oxygen gas by combustion. Hydrocarbons are a significant portion of the fossil fuels that are burned to produce energy. Complete combustion of hydro-carbon fuels produces carbon dioxide, water vapor, and energy.

Examples of hydrocarbon combustion reactions:<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>C<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>5</sub>OH(l) + 3O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) → 2CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + 3H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(g) + Energy</br> CH<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>(g) + 2O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) → CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + 2H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(g) + Energy

Evidence for the occurrence of chemical reactions includes precipitate formation, gas evolution, pH change, heat release or absorption, or color change. Any one of these events can indicate a chemical reaction. If a chemical reaction results in the production of a gaseous product, then simple chemical tests can be used to confirm gaseous reaction products. These chemical tests are also chemical reactions.

pageData.question: Which of the following is an example of a double-replacement reaction?

C<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>5</sub>OH(l) + 3O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) ➝ 2CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + 3H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(g) + Energy
H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>(aq) ➝ H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O(l) + CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>(g) + Heat

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: One type of double-replacement reaction is an acid-base reaction, in which a reaction occurs between an acid and a base. A hydronium ion (H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup>) reacts with a hydroxide ion (OH<sup class=bodySupscript>-</sup>) to form water, and the cation and anion form an aqueous salt.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In a synthesis reaction, two or more reactants combine to make a single new product. In a decomposition reaction, a single reactant compound breaks down to form two or more new products. Single-replacement reactions occur when a single element in one reactant replaces a similar single element in another reactant. This reaction is sometimes called a displacement or substitution reaction. In double-replacement reactions, two ionic compounds exchange ions to produce two new ionic compounds.  Combustion reactions involve a single element or compound that combines with oxygen gas to release heat and light.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In a synthesis reaction, two or more reactants combine to make a single new product. In a decomposition reaction, a single reactant compound breaks down to form two or more new products. Single-replacement reactions occur when a single element in one reactant replaces a similar single element in another reactant. This reaction is sometimes called a displacement or substitution reaction. In double-replacement reactions, two ionic compounds exchange ions to produce two new ionic compounds.  Combustion reactions involve a single element or compound that combines with oxygen gas to release heat and light.

pageData.text: Oxygen Gas: To test for oxygen gas, insert a glowing splint into a container of collected gas (Figure 1). If the splint bursts back into flame, the test is positive for oxygen gas. Oxygen supports combustion, and the oxygen-rich environment inside the container causes the glowing splint to burn. Sometimes the glowing splint can create a small pop when first exposed to the oxygen.

Hydrogen Gas: To test for hydrogen gas, insert a flaming splint into a container of collected gas held at a 45-degree angle (Figure 2). If a loud pop or barking sound is heard, the test is positive for hydrogen gas. The hydrogen gas will react with oxygen in the atmosphere when ignited as follows:2H2(g) + O2(g) ➝ 2H2O(g) + Energy

image.desc: Figure 1: To test for oxygen gas, insert a glowing splint into a container of collected gas held upright at a 45-degree angle
image.altText: Figure 1: To test for oxygen gas, insert a glowing splint into a container of collected gas held upright at a 45-degree angle

image.desc: Figure 2: To test for hydrogen gas, insert a flaming splint into a container of collected gas held upside down at a 45-degree angle
image.altText: Figure 2: To test for hydrogen gas, insert a flaming splint into a container of collected gas held upside down at a 45-degree angle

pageData.text: Carbon Dioxide Gas: To test for carbon dioxide gas, bubble the collected gas through lime-water. If a precipitate forms, the test is positive for carbon dioxide gas. The carbon dioxide gas [CO2(g)] reacts with the limewater [Ca(OH)2(aq)] to produce insoluble CaCO3 and water as follows:CO2(g) + Ca(OH)2(aq) ➝ CaCO3(s) + H2O(l)
A glowing or burning splint will extinguish in carbon dioxide, but this is not a decisive test. In addition to carbon dioxide, there are other gasses that also do not support combustion.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes a decisive positive test for carbon dioxide gas?

options.text: bubbling the gas through limewater and observing precipitate formation
placing a burning splint in the gas and observing the flame extinguished
placing a glowing splint in the gas and observing a loud popping sound
placing a glowing splint in the gas and observing the splint burning
bubbling the gas through limewater and observing a color change

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: To test for carbon dioxide gas, bubble the collected gas through limewater. If a precipitate forms, the test is positive for carbon dioxide gas. Extinguishing a burning splint with the collected gas is not a decisive test as there are other gases that also do not support combustion.

pageData.desc:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will need to prepare magnesium ribbon. Then you will need to assemble gas collection stopper. 
Next Prepare glass test tubes 
In Activity 1, you will need to observe reaction between steel wool and vinegar. Next measure change in steel wool temperature. 
In Activity 2, you will need to observe catalyzed breakdown of hydrogen peroxide. Then test for gaseous products 
In Activity 3, you will need to observe reaction between magnesium metal and hydrochloric acid. Next test for gaseous products.
pageData.altText:
This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will need to prepare magnesium ribbon. Then you will need to assemble gas collection stopper. 
Next Prepare glass test tubes 
In Activity 1, you will need to observe reaction between steel wool and vinegar. Next measure change in steel wool temperature. 
In Activity 2, you will need to observe catalyzed breakdown of hydrogen peroxide. Then test for gaseous products 
In Activity 3, you will need to observe reaction between magnesium metal and hydrochloric acid. Next test for gaseous products.

pageData.desc:
In Activity 4, you will need to observe reaction between vinegar and baking soda. Then test for gaseous products. 
In activity 5, you will need to light a candle and collect gaseous products. Then restart reaction from Activity 4. Next test for additional gaseous products using lit candle. 
In Activity 6, you will need to bubble gaseous products of vinegar-baking soda reaction through limewater. Next record qualitative observations. 
In activity 7, you will need to observe reaction of steel wool burning. Next record qualitative observations.
pageData.altText:
In Activity 4, you will need to observe reaction between vinegar and baking soda. Then test for gaseous products. 
In activity 5, you will need to light a candle and collect gaseous products. Then restart reaction from Activity 4. Next test for additional gaseous products using lit candle. 
In Activity 6, you will need to bubble gaseous products of vinegar-baking soda reaction through limewater. Next record qualitative observations. 
In activity 7, you will need to observe reaction of steel wool burning. Next record qualitative observations.

Wear your safety goggles, chemical apron, and gloves at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.
Hydrogen peroxide, vinegar, and baking soda are not packaged for household consumption or use. They should be considered chemicals and kept away from children and pets.
Magnesium metal ribbon is a combustible metal. Keep chemical away from any heat or flame sources.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Vinegar and hydrogen peroxide cause skin and eye irritation.
pageData.altText: warning symbol
corrosion symbol
pageData.text: Limewater, hydrogen peroxide, and hydrochloric acid are corrosive materials. Use these materials near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eyewash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Glass test tubes are provided in the Investigating Chemical Reactions materials kit and are more resistant to heat and chemicals than the polystyrene (plastic) test tubes in the equipment kit. Use the glass test tubes as instructed in the Investigating Chemical Reactions manual. If a glass test tube breaks, carefully clean up the broken glass, and dispose of it in an appropriate way.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Peter is testing the gas collected from a chemical reaction to determine its identity. He inserts a glowing splint into the container of collected gas. The splint emits a "pop" sound. Which of the following gases is most likely in the container?

assestmentData.pageTitle: Drag and Drop Knowledge Check Question
assestmentData.question: Match each type of reaction with its description.

options.text: two or more reactants produce a single product
a single reactant forms two or more new products
a single element in one reactant replaces a similar single element in another reactant
two ionic compounds exchange ions to produce new ionic compounds
a single reactant and oxygen produce light and heat

assestmentData.question: Combining 2 H<sup class=bodySupscript>+</sup> and O<sup class=bodySupscript>2-</sup> to produce H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O is an example of which type of reaction?

Living organisms require energy. Sugar can be used as an energy source when it is broken down into smaller, simpler molecules, releasing heat in the process. Which type of reaction does this represent?

options.text: This is not a chemical reaction.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is LEAST likely to be evidence for the occurrence of a chemical reaction?

The balanced equation below represents which type of chemical reaction?<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>2 C<sub class=bodySubscript>4</sub>H<sub class=bodySubscript>10</sub> + 13 O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> → 8 CO<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + 10 H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O + heat

The balanced equation below represents which type of chemical reaction?<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>Pb(NO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>)<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> + Na<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>CO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub> → PbCO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub> + 2 NaNO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>
When choosing between glass and plastic test tubes to use in this investigation, which of the following guidelines should you follow?

options.text: Use the test tubes as instructed in the lab manual.
Use the glass test tubes only when collecting gases.
Use the plastic test tubes only when using corrosive reactants.
Use either type of test tube for any of the reactions in the investigation.
Use the plastic test tubes if the glass test tubes break.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses glass test tubes. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: Several chemicals are provided in your lab kit for this investigation. Which of the following describes the corrosive chemicals in this investigation?

options.text: limewater, hydrogen peroxide, and hydrochloric acid
vinegar, hydrogen peroxide, and hydrochloric acid
baking soda, limewater, and hydrogen peroxide

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Use a pair of scissors to cut a 1-cm piece of magnesium ribbon for Activity 3.
Assemble the gas-collection stopper for Activity 6.
1. Use scissors to remove the tip and bulb from a plastic disposable pipet to create a 2-inch plastic tube.

pageData.desc: Figure 3a: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4
pageData.altText: Figure 3a: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4

pageData.text: 1. Insert the plastic pipette tube into the hole in the large #4 rubber stopper. Use the forceps to squeeze the tube and push it through the hole. A small drop of soap inside the dropper hole will help this process.

pageData.desc: Figure 3b: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4
pageData.altText: Figure 3b: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4

pageData.text: 1. Connect airline tubing to the top (the larger end) of the plastic pipette tube extending from the top of the rubber stopper.

pageData.desc: Figure 3c: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4
pageData.altText: Figure 3c: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4

pageData.text: Optional: Wrap a rubber band around each glass test tube to prevent it from rolling off the table/workstation and potentially breaking.

Three different test tubes are used in this investigation. The materials kit contains a large glass test tube. The equipment kit contains a smaller glass test tube and polystyrene (plastic) test tubes. Carefully read the instructions to ensure that the correct test tube (or tubes) is used during each activity.

In Activity 1, you will observe a <button class='glossary-text'>synthesis reaction</button> between steel wool and vinegar. Be sure to save the vinegar from this activity for use in Activity 4. You will measure the change in temperature of the steel wool during the reaction and record qualitative observations.
Measure 50 mL of white vinegar in the graduated cylinder, and then pour it into the small cup.
Measure the room temperature using a thermometer, and record the measurement in Data Table 1.
Place the thermometer and a rubber band on a paper towel.

While wearing protective gloves, tear or cut the steel-wool pad in half. Place one of the halves of steel wool on the paper towel. This half will be used later for comparison. Assume that this piece of steel wool remains at room temperature.

Place the other half of steel wool in the cup containing the white vinegar, and gently press it down to completely submerge it in the vinegar. Keep this steel wool submerged in the vinegar for 2 minutes.

Vinegar does not participate in the <button class='glossary-text'>synthesis reaction</button>. In this procedure, vinegar strips away the protective coating on the steel-wool pad, and provides an acidic environment that accelerates the subsequent chemical reaction.
Remove the steel wool from the cup, and carefully squeeze the excess vinegar back into the cup. Keep the small cup of vinegar for use in Activity 4.
Wrap the damp steel wool piece around the bulb of the thermometer, and secure it in place with the rubber band.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Steel wool and thermometer assembly as described in step 7
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Steel wool and thermometer assembly as described in step 7

pageData.text: Place the steel-wool-wrapped thermometer on the paper towel.
Record the temperature of the damp steel wool. Start the timer.
Observe the synthesis reaction for 10 minutes. Record the temperature of the steel wool at 5 and 10 minutes after the start of the synthesis reaction. Enter your data into Data Table 1.

The thermometer may have to be slid part-way out of the steel wool to observe the temperature scale, and then quickly slid back into the steel wool. Do not touch the bulb end of the thermometer during this procedure.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: At 10 minutes after the start of the synthesis reaction, compare the appearance of the vinegar-treated steel wool to that of the dry steel wool. Record your observations in Data Table 1. Photograph your observations.
Remove the thermometer from the steel wool.
Rinse the thermometer and graduated cylinder with purified water, and dry with paper towels.
Discard paper towels, steel wool, and rubber band in the trash.
In Activity 2, you will observe the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide as catalyzed by an enzyme in yeast. You will test any gaseous products and record qualitative observations.
Measure 10 mL of hydrogen peroxide (H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>) solution in the graduated cylinder, and then pour it into the large glass test tube.
Place the large test tube containing H<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>O<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub> upright in a clean, empty, 250-mL beaker.
Use the plastic minispoon to measure two level spoonfuls of dry yeast; add both spoonfuls to the hydrogen peroxide solution in the large test tube. Start the timer.
Yeast is not part of the decomposition reaction. Yeast contains a protein that catalyzes the reaction.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Observe the for 1 minute, and record your observations in Data Table 1. Photograph your observations.
Gently swirl the contents of the large test tube for one minute and record your observations in Data Table 1.

Using the information described in “Standard Tests for Gaseous Products” predict the result of 6a and 6b.
  1. Insert a glowing splint into the large test tube. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
  2. Insert a flaming splint into the large test tube. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
After finishing Step 6, dispose of the contents of the large test tube down the drain.
Thoroughly rinse the 250-mL beaker and large test tube with purified water, and dry them with paper towels.
In Activity 3, you will observe a single-replacement reaction between magnesium metal and hydrochloric acid. You will test any gaseous products and record qualitative observations.
Cut a 1-cm strip off of the longer strip of magnesium.
Insert the 1-cm strip of magnesium a few millimeters into the hole on the smaller tapered end of the small, #00 1-hole rubber stopper as shown in Figure 5.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Magnesium in rubber stopper

pageData.text: Fill the 250-mL beaker with tap water to within 3 centimeters from the rim.
Using the 10-mL graduated cylinder, measure 3 mL of 1 M HCl, and add it to the small glass test tube.
Add 50 mL of purified water to the 50-mL graduated cylinder.
Hold the small glass test tube containing the HCl at a 45-degree angle.

Use the plastic pipette to slowly add the water from the graduated cylinder to the test tube containing the HCl. Try to layer the water on top of the HCl by gently pipetting the water down the side of the glass test tube.
The objective is to contain the solution of hydrochloric acid at the bottom of the test tube to prevent the reaction from starting too quickly in Step 9.
Continue filling the glass test tube by repeating Step 6 until the water level is within one centimeter from the top of the test tube.

Hold the glass test tube over the beaker, and then carefully insert the stopper fitted with the magnesium strip into the opening of the glass test tube. Allow any overflow water to drain into the beaker.

Place your forefinger over the hole in the rubber stopper, carefully invert the test tube, and then place the inverted test tube into the beaker of water, allowing it to rest in the beaker at a 45-degree angle as seen in Figure 6. Start the timer.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Reaction apparatus final assembly

pageData.text: Observe the single-replacement reaction for 10 minutes. Record your observations in Data Table 1.

As the glass test tube fills with gas, water escapes through the hole in the rubber stopper. Once the water is completely expelled from the glass test tube, bubbles will begin to emerge from the hole in the rubber stopper. When this happens, pick up the glass test tube, and hold it vertically with the rubber stopper at the bottom.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak> The gases in the test tube are lighter than air, so keep the test tube inverted (with the opening pointing downward).
Carefully remove the stopper, and place the opening of the inverted glass test tube on a level surface. A tube full of a gas has been collected.
Refer to the section describing the standard tests for confirming gases (“Standard Tests for Gaseous Products”). Pick up the glass test tube and hold it, still inverted, at a 45-degree angle.
Insert a flaming splint into the opening of the glass test tube. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
Thoroughly rinse the 250-mL beaker, rubber stopper, and glass test tube with purified water. Dry each of them with a paper towel.

In Activity 4, you will observe a double-displacement reaction between vinegar and baking soda. You will use the vinegar saved from Activity 1. You will test any gaseous products and record qualitative observations. Be sure to save the vinegar and baking soda solution for use in Activity 5.
Locate the cup containing 50 mL of vinegar that was saved from Activity 1.
Use a weighing boat to measure 10 g of baking soda (sodium bicarbonate, NaHCO<sub class=bodySubscript>3</sub>) on the balance.
Pour the baking soda into the small cup containing the vinegar.
Loosely cover the cup with a small piece of paper towel to retain more of the gas in the cup. Start the timer.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Observe the double-displacement reaction for 1 minute. Photograph your observations.
Gently swirl the contents of the cup to complete the reaction. Remove the small piece of paper towel covering the top of the cup, and observe the contents.
Record your observations in Data Table 1.

Refer to the section describing the standard tests for confirming gases (“Standard Tests for Gaseous Products” in the Background section).
  1. Insert a glowing splint into the small cup. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
  2. Insert a flaming splint into the small cup. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
Keep the small cup containing vinegar and baking soda to use in Activity 5.
Keep the weighing boat used for measuring the baking soda to use in Activity 6.

In Activity 5, you will observe a <button class='glossary-text'>combustion reaction</button> as you light the wick of a tea candle. You will record qualitative observations of the gaseous products collected from this reaction. You will also use the lit candle to test for an additional gaseous product of the vinegar and baking soda reaction from Activity 4.
Light the candle with a match (or a lighter). The fuel that supports burning of the wick is paraffin.
CAUTION: Hold the test tube opening a centimeter above the flame to capture all the gases. Hold the test tube at the opposite end away from the flame, so that you do not burn your fingers.

Hold the small glass test tube in an inverted position (with the opening facing downward) over the candle wick for 30 seconds. This collects the gases released by the burning candle. After 30 seconds, move the inverted test tube away from the flame. Keep the test tube inverted.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Record your observations of the gasses collected in the small test tube in Data Table 1. Photograph your observations.
Locate the small cup containing the vinegar and baking soda from Activity 4.
Slowly add another 50 mL of white vinegar to the small cup.
Carefully pour the gasses that are generated over the candle flame.
Record your observations in Data Table 1.

Convection currents may have removed gas. Adding additional vinegar will regenerate the gas.<span class=bodyParaLineBreak>To pour the gases, hold the small cup over the candle, and tilt it as far as possible while keeping the vinegar and baking soda retained inside the cup.
If necessary, extinguish the candle flame.
Pour the remaining vinegar and baking soda solution down the drain, and flush with excess water.
Thoroughly rinse the small cup with purified water, and dry it with a paper towel.

In Activity 6, you will use the gas collection apparatus to bubble the gaseous products of a vinegar-baking soda reaction through limewater and observe a precipitation reaction. You will record qualitative observations.
Locate the gas-collection stopper with the plastic pipet tube that was constructed during the Preparation steps (Figure 3).
Use the weighing boat, and measure 5 g of baking soda using the electronic balance. Add this 5 g of baking soda to the large test tube.
It is easier to pour the baking soda into the large test tube by carefully folding the weighing boat diagonally, which creates a spout.
Place the large test tube containing the baking soda into the 250-mL beaker.
Measure 10 mL of white vinegar in the 50-mL graduated cylinder. Pour this 10 mL of vinegar into the polystyrene test tube.
The polystyrene test tube is thinner and shorter than the large test tube, so it fits completely inside the large test tube.
Place the polystyrene test tube containing the vinegar into the large test tube containing the baking soda. Both test tubes should be in upright positions (with the openings facing upward).
Carefully insert the gas-collection stopper into the large test tube, which is resting in the beaker. The plastic tubing will hang freely out of the beaker.
Add limewater to the small glass test tube until the tube is approximately one-half full.
Limewater contains calcium hydroxide, Ca(OH)<sub class=bodySubscript>2</sub>, dissolved in water.
Place the glass test tube containing the limewater in the cardboard test-tube rack.
Tilt the large test tube horizontally, so that vinegar pours out of the polystyrene test tube into the larger test tube, and reacts with the baking soda.
As soon as the reaction starts, stop adding vinegar to the reaction and quickly place the free end of the plastic tubing into the limewater solution in the small test tube.

The vinegar and baking soda react to generate carbon dioxide gas. The gas is then bubbled into the limewater. The first gas to come out of the tube will be mostly air until the large test tube fills up with the carbon dioxide gas. Place the end of the plastic tube as far into the limewater solution as possible to increase the reaction time.

As the generation of carbon dioxide slows, again tilt the large test tube to pour more vinegar into the baking soda. Be careful that the plastic tubing remains immersed in the limewater. Repeat this step until all the vinegar is consumed.
Observe the limewater solution and record your observations in Data Table 1.
Swirl the large test tube to complete the reaction of all the vinegar and baking soda.
When no more gas is generated, remove the plastic tubing from the limewater solution. Start the timer. Allow the limewater solution to sit, undisturbed, for 5 minutes.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: After 5 minutes, record any additional observations in Data Table 1. Photograph your observations.
In Activity 7, you will observe a second <button class='glossary-text'>combustion reaction</button> as you set light to a sample of steel wool. You will record qualitative observations.
Gently pull apart the unused half of the steel-wool pad from Activity 1. Use approximately ¼ of the remaining steel-wool pad for this activity.
The steel wool is tightly packed; by pulling the fibers apart, more surface area is exposed. The steel-wool fibers should be visible and separated from one another.
Light the candle.
Hold the steel wool with the forceps over a cookie sheet or large plate.
CAUTION: The cookie sheet will catch any burning particles from the steel wool and protect the counter top or table.
Attempt to ignite the steel-wool fibers with the flame of the candle.
Record any observations in Data Table 1.

text: Ensure that each used wooden splint is extinguished by dipping each used splint into water.
Discard weighing boat, wooden splints, paper towels, and nitrile gloves in the trash.
Wash and dry the beaker, test tubes, graduated cylinders, minispoon, rubber stopper, small cup, forceps, and thermometer.
Clean and sanitize the work space.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

text: Describe all of the signs that indicated a chemical reaction occurred.
Describe the temperature change that occurred during this reaction. Is heat required or produced during the reaction?
Describe any other changes that were observed in the steel wool. What reaction might create such a change?
Write a balanced equation for the reaction of the steel wool with oxygen. Be sure to include heat energy in the reaction.
What two gases could potentially be produced from decomposing hydrogen peroxide? Which gas was actually produced? What non-gaseous product formed from the reaction?
Write a balanced equation for the decomposition of hydrogen peroxide.
What gases could potentially be produced from hydrochloric acid (HCl)? Which gas was actually produced?
Why did the splint need to be tilted at a 45-degree angle?

nestedOrderList: Write a balanced equation for the reaction initiated by the burning splint.
Classify the reaction initiated by the burning splint.

text: Write a balanced equation for the reaction of magnesium with hydrochloric acid.
What is the name and molecular formula of the gas formed when baking soda was combined with vinegar, which you identified using flaming and glowing splints?
Write a balanced chemical equation for the double-replacement reaction that occurred when baking soda was combined with vinegar.

One of the two products of the reaction of baking soda and vinegar is carbonic acid (H2CO3), which immediately forms water and the gas you identified after exposure to the flaming and glowing splints. Write a balanced equation showing the decomposition of carbonic acid.
Explain why water appeared on the inside of the glass test tube.
Write a balanced equation for the combustion reaction.
Write a balanced equation for the precipitation reaction. Which product is the precipitate?

pageData.altText: Periodic Table of the Elements
Figure 1: To test for oxygen gas, insert a glowing splint into a container of collected gas held upright at a 45-degree angle
Figure 2: To test for hydrogen gas, insert a flaming splint into a container of collected gas held upside down at a 45-degree angle

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. 
You will need to prepare magnesium ribbon. Then you will need to assemble gas collection stopper. 
Next Prepare glass test tubes 
In Activity 1, you will need to observe reaction between steel wool and vinegar. Next measure change in steel wool temperature. 
In Activity 2, you will need to observe catalyzed breakdown of hydrogen peroxide. Then test for gaseous products 
In Activity 3, you will need to observe reaction between magnesium metal and hydrochloric acid. Next test for gaseous products.

In Activity 4, you will need to observe reaction between vinegar and baking soda. Then test for gaseous products. 
In activity 5, you will need to light a candle and collect gaseous products. Then restart reaction from Activity 4. Next test for additional gaseous products using lit candle. 
In Activity 6, you will need to bubble gaseous products of vinegar-baking soda reaction through limewater. Next record qualitative observations. 
In activity 7, you will need to observe reaction of steel wool burning. Next record qualitative observations.
Figure 3: Assembling gas collection stopper as described in step 4
pageData.content: Figure 3. How to assemble gas collection stopper

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Steel wool and thermometer assembly as described in step 7
Figure 5: Magnesium in rubber stopper

data.title: Combustion reaction
data.content: Involve a single element or compound that combines with oxygen gas to release heat and light (commonly called burning).

data.title: Decomposition reaction
data.content: A single reactant compound breaks down to form two or more new products.

data.title: Double-replacement reactions
data.content: Two ionic compounds exchange ions to produce two new ionic compounds.

data.title: Single-replacement reactions
data.content: Occur when a single element in one reactant replaces a similar single element in another reactant.

data.title: Synthesis reaction
data.content: Two or more reactants combine to make a single new product.
